document: Chapter 4: Processing Crime and Incident Scenes - Guide to Computer Forensics and Investigations, Fifth Edition

questions.question: Digital evidence can be any information stored or transmitted in digital form.
Courts do not accept digital evidence as physical evidence.
SWGDE sets standards for recovering, preserving, and examining digital evidence.
Consistent practices help verify work and enhance credibility in evidence handling.
Digital evidence is easier to detect changes in than other physical evidence.
Most federal courts consider computer records as direct evidence rather than hearsay.
The business-record exception allows certain business records to be admissible in court.
Computer-generated records are considered authentic if the creating program is functioning correctly.
The best evidence rule requires original documents, recordings, or photographs.
Bit-stream copies can never be admitted in court as evidence.
Private-sector organizations include businesses and non-law enforcement government agencies.
FOIA allows citizens to request copies of private corporate documents.
ISPs can investigate computer abuse by their customers without restrictions.
Corporate policy statements allow covert surveillance with little or no cause.
Warning banners reserve the right to inspect computing assets at will.
Corporate investigators are primarily concerned with prosecuting employees.
If evidence of a crime is found during a company policy investigation, you should continue investigating without informing management.
Probable cause is required for law enforcement to obtain a search warrant.
The Fourth Amendment requires warrants to specifically describe places to be searched and items to be seized.
Innocent information is always excluded from search warrants.
The plain view doctrine is fully acceptable in digital forensics.
Plain view doctrine requires that any discovery must be by chance.
Preparing for a computer search and seizure is the least important step in computing investigations.
The nature of the case dictates how you proceed in an investigation.
For law enforcement, identifying the OS or device at a crime scene is always easy.
Law enforcement investigators always need a warrant to remove computers from a crime scene.
Cloud storage can be physically located and seized easily.
HAZMAT guidelines recommend putting target drives in special bags for decontamination.
Corporate computing investigations usually require multiple people to respond to an incident.
Technical expertise is never needed for processing incident or crime scenes.
An initial-response field kit should include all possible tools.
The goal of scene processing is to collect and secure digital evidence.
Digital evidence is non-volatile and remains unchanged over time.
Yellow barrier tape is used to define a secure perimeter.
AFIS is used to identify fingerprints connected to a central database.
Corporate investigators always need a warrant to seize evidence.
Civil investigations require more documentation than criminal investigations.
When arriving at a scene, you should always cut electrical power to a running system immediately.
Sparse acquisition extracts only data related to evidence from allocated files.
A journal is unnecessary for documenting activities during evidence processing.
